title: What is the forbidden riff? - Quora

response.answer_text: The ‘forbidden riff’ is a guitar shop in-joke which began in Denmark Street, London, in about 1973. Guitar-shop workers were fed-up of hearing beginners butcher Stairway to Heaven, Whole lotta love, and various other standards, and then look around for admiration. What’s worse, the people who came in to try out Stairway were well-known as the ones least likely to buy a guitar. So they put up a list of ‘forbidden songs’, which included the aforementioned, plus some other classics. These lists were copied from shop to shop, and the lists got extended. Smoke on the Water is one of the earliest non-Zeppelin riffs, Seven Nation Army is the most recent to have achieved the doubtful glory of making its way onto them. There is no standard list. If you look like you are going to buy an instrument, most guitar shops will let you play whatever you like. However, if you come in every week with your mates, try a few guitars and play one of the listed songs, they are likely to point to the list on the wall and tell you ‘time’s up’. What makes these particular riffs and intros especially annoying is: Every beginner guitarist learns themEvery beginner guitarist acts like they think they are the only ones ever to learn themBeginner guitarists usually play them badly.Experienced guitarists are less likely to randomly try out instruments, and more likely to play something interesting that the shop owners haven’t heard before. Want to know if you impressed someone? It’s when they start asking you for advice. If they don’t, you didn’t impress them, no matter how much they say ‘really good mate’ or ‘that’s the best thing I’ve heard all day’. Guitar shop workers are mostly guitarists, and they are extremely hard to impress.  Inexperienced guitarist interested in trying out a few guitars, so that his mates can hear him play ‘Stairway’. …walks into shop. Guitarist: “Excuse me, is it ok if I try… the guitars?” Shop worker: “Hmph” — points to a couple of cheap guitars with strings caked in grime, which are kept especially for this purpose. Guitarist (sits down. His mates stand up to look in awe): “This is something I’ve been working on. You may recognise it.” Begins first chords of Smoke on the Water. Gets as far as the end of the riff, and immediately switches to Stairway to Heaven. Gets lost at the bit where the mellotron comes in. Guitar shop worker is desperately hoping he won’t hum the mellotron part, or, even worse, whistle. Switches to Seven Nation Army. Guitar shop worker: “That’s really great mate. Good on you. We erm, well, actually have a policy against those particular songs. Can I interest you in some new strings? Or maybe a pick? I’ve got these stickers you can have for nothing.” Guitarist gets the message, and heads off with his mates to hang around on a street corner.  Experienced guitarist intent on buying a guitar. …walks into shop. Guitarist: “Is Dave in?” Shop worker: “He’s in the back. Shall I get him for you?” Guitarist: “That would be really good — hey didn’t I see you playing at the Guitar and Grog pub last week?” Shop worker: “Yeah, that’s right. With my band the Dead Pigeons.” Guitarist: “Fantastic. Dave, you said…” Shop worker: “On it.” Dave: “Hello mate. What can I do for you today?” Guitarist: “I’ve come into a bit of money—not much, mind— and I want to buy something a bit special—but, I need to say, I really need you to go out on a limb for me on the price. Can you help me on that?” Dave: “Which guitar was it?” Guitarist: “Show me the one you’d buy.” Dave: “Well, there is a guitar which is a bit special, but we’ve already cut the price right down.” Guitarist: “Dave…! It’s me. You’ve got to help a musician.” Dave: “Well, I suppose I could look at the label with you. Yeah, I think we might be able to do something here. But just for you, mind. Don’t go telling anyone else.” … Negotiation continues. Guitarist eventually leaves shop with a guitar priced 20% below the marked price, which is still 20% more than Dave bought it for. Dave swears that Guitarist is almost bankrupting him. Guitarist swears that he’ll be eating bread roll for a month to pay for it. He then puts the guitar in the back of his Mercedes and drives off.  Experienced guitarists know that the most important part of buying a guitar, assuming it’s the guitar you want, is getting to the right price. Playing forbidden songs, spending the entire afternoon ‘just trying it out’, or anything else which will annoy the staff, are all eating into the discount. Make friends with everyone. Make your mind up quickly, pay, and leave. And don’t play Stairway. Ever.
